text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Kenya's ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party says it will recommend the publishing of a Bill for enactment by the current parliament to provide for the establishment of a commission to review the constitution.
- The National Convention Executive Council says it will push ahead with plans for mass action despite recent talks between President Daniel arap Moi, the clergy and the opposition.
- President Moi says using force such as in the clamour for reforms is unacceptable and advises leaders to seek dialogue.
- Opposition leaders give President Moi a set of nine-preconditions for discussing constitutional reforms with him next week.
- Two "most-wanted" carjackers are gunned down by police.
- The University of Nairobi and Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology are scheduled to reopen next week.
- Kenya protests to the United States government for placing a quarantine on Americans wishing to travel to the country, citing insecurity.
- A move by an opposition legislator from western Kenya to marry a second wife so as to boost his bid for parliament has polarised his family and supporters.
- The Electoral Commission is preparing a code of conduct to curb violence in the forthcoming general election.
- Illegal registration of voters is still going on in certain areas of the country, a fortnight after the official end of the exercise by the Electoral Commission.
- KANU's sudden change of heart to embrace constitutional reforms comes as unexpectedly as it is suspicious. ($1=59 Kenyan Shillings)
